title: 109_hr5707
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cruise Line Accurate Safety Statistics Act" and requires reporting of crimes and other information. The "Cruise Line Accurate Safety Statistics Act" mandates that cruise ship owners report covered crimes and incidents involving missing or overboard US citizens within specific timeframes to the Secretary. Additionally, crimes occurring on the cruise ship must be reported quarterly. The "Cruise Line Accurate Safety Statistics Act" requires cruise ship owners to report crimes and incidents involving missing or overboard individuals within specific timeframes to the Secretary. The Secretary must make this information available to the public, including on a website. SEC. 3. INSPECTION OF CRUISE SHIPS. The Secretary will inspect cruise ships entering US ports to ensure they have necessary equipment and trained personnel to investigate crimes. Regulations will define requirements. SEC. 4. DISCLOSURES BY CRUISE LINES. SEC. 4. DISCLOSURES BY CRUISE LINES. Cruise lines selling tickets for US port calls must provide country visit details and US embassy/consulate locations to passengers. The Secretary will define cruise line criteria. A person owning a cruise ship can be fined up to $250,000 for failing to report, not having adequate equipment, or not providing required information to ticket purchasers. The Secretary will assess the penalty, and the cruise ship itself can be held liable. The Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates can deny entry into the United States to a cruise vessel if the owner commits certain acts or fails to pay a civil penalty imposed under this section. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "covered crime" includes acts or omissions that would violate various sections of title 18, United States Code, such as arson, maiming, certain crimes within special maritime and territorial jurisdiction, murder, manslaughter, and kidnapping. The term "cruise ship" refers to any vessel over 100 gross registered tons capable of carrying more than 12 passengers for hire on a voyage lasting more than 24 hours, part of which is on the high seas. A cruise ship is a vessel over 100 gross registered tons that carries more than 12 passengers for hire on voyages lasting more than 24 hours, including time on the high seas, and embarks or disembarks passengers in the United States. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates.
